channel.title: Culture: TV, Movies, Music, Art, and Theatre News and Reviews
channel.description: Cultural news and criticism, and conversations about TV, theatre, movies, and music, as well as Goings On About Town listings from The New Yorker.

item.title: “Waiting to Exhale,” Thirty Years On
item.description: The 1995 classic became as much a sociological phenomenon as an artistic one—but its designation as a “chick flick” belies its emotional sophistication and intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Niela Orr

item.title: Is the Dictionary Done For?
item.description: The print edition of Merriam-Webster was once a touchstone of authority and stability. Then the internet brought about a revolution.
item.dc:creator: Louis Menand

item.title: The Burgled Louvre’s Stolen-Art Expert
item.description: Bénédicte Savoy is Europe’s leading advocate for the repatriation of cultural heritage. Now, in the wake of a shocking heist, she’s bringing her ideas to the Louvre.
item.media:keywords: Art History, Art Historian, Louvre, Museums
item.dc:creator: Julian Lucas

item.title: What if Readers Like A.I.-Generated Fiction?
item.description: If economic and technological transformations have changed our relationship with literature before, they could do so again.
item.dc:creator: Vauhini Vara

item.title: How to Reclaim Your Mind
item.description: To feel mentally alive, you have to do more than defeat distraction.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rothman

item.title: Briefly Noted
item.description: “Daring to Be Free,” “The Second Estate,” “Best Offer Wins,” and “A Love Story from the End of the World.”

item.title: The Psychology of Fashion
item.description: Our garments offer glimpses of the unconscious; we may also choose them because they feel nothing like us—because they allow us, briefly, to become someone else.
item.dc:creator: Leslie Jamison

item.title: What to Read Before Your Trip to Atropia
item.description: Hailey Benton Gates, the director of the “military-industrial-complex romantic comedy” “Atropia,” recommends a few books that share a kinship with her new film, about actors working in a fake village where U.S. soldiers train.
item.media:keywords: Disable Inline Signup Unit, Iraq War, Military, Army

item.title: The Best Books of 2025
item.description: The New Yorker’s editors and critics choose this year’s essential reads in fiction, poetry, and nonfiction.

item.title: “No Other Choice” Eliminates the Competition with Style
item.description: In Park Chan-wook’s adaptation of Donald E. Westlake’s crime novel, Lee Byung-hun plays a newly laid-off executive who launches his own campaign of mass termination.
item.dc:creator: Justin Chang

item.title: “Father Mother Sister Brother” Explores the Mysteries of Family Life
item.description: Jim Jarmusch’s three-part drama, set in New Jersey, Dublin, and Paris, casts such notables as Adam Driver and Cate Blanchett in wry, ironic probes of grown children’s relationships with their parents.
item.media:keywords: Jim Jarmusch, Movies, Films, Adam Driver, Cate Blanchett, Family, Families, Siblings
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody

item.title: “Marty Supreme” ’s Megawatt Personality
item.description: In Josh Safdie’s hectic new film, Timothée Chalamet plays a gifted Ping-Pong player who’s also a born performer.
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody

item.title: The Delirious Cinematic Artifice of Bi Gan’s “Resurrection”
item.description: In the Chinese director’s third feature, the pop idol Jackson Yee plays a shape-shifting dreamer who gets lost in a densely allusive maze of stories and genres.
item.dc:creator: Justin Chang

item.title: The Best Things I Ate in 2025
item.description: Our restaurant critic rounds up her favorite menu items from a year of eating out.
item.dc:creator: Helen Rosner

item.title: A New Afghan Bakery, in New York’s Golden Age of Bread
item.description: The city has vaunted sourdough loaves and endlessly hyped croissants. Diljān, in Brooklyn Heights, brings a classic Afghan flatbread into the mix.
item.category: Magazine / On and Off the Menu
item.dc:creator: Hannah Goldfield

item.title: Restaurant Review: Babbo
item.description: Under the chef Mark Ladner, the famous Greenwich Village trattoria aims for selective nostalgia.
item.dc:creator: Helen Rosner

item.title: A Holiday Gift Guide: Gear for the Coffee Nerd
item.description: Our staff expert recommends a collection of grinders, kettles, and other devices worth poring over.
item.category: Culture / On and Off the Avenue
item.dc:creator: Kelefa Sanneh

item.title: Tyler Mitchell’s Art-Historical Mood Board
item.description: The thirty-year-old star photographer became famous for his reference-rich images of Black beauty, but his strongest work suggests a tender eye for imperfection.
item.dc:creator: Chris Wiley

item.title: The Extremely Online Bona Fides of “I Love L.A.”
item.description: Rachel Sennott, the HBO series’ creator and star, may be a relative newcomer to Los Angeles, but she’s a native of the show’s true setting: the internet.
item.media:keywords: Los Angeles, Influencers, Social Media, TV Shows, HBO, Series
item.dc:creator: Inkoo Kang

item.title: The Best TV Shows of 2025
item.description: This year, Hollywood’s decline was evident from its output—but a few great, conversation-starting shows made our critic crave the return of the water cooler.
item.media:keywords: Television, Year in Review, Series, Shows, Streaming
item.dc:creator: Inkoo Kang

item.title: TV Review: Tim Robinson’s “The Chair Company,” on HBO
item.description: The comedian’s new HBO series is full of characters who possess their own sparks of madness.
item.dc:creator: Molly Fischer

item.title: “Landman” Goes Down Like a Michelob Ultra
item.description: Taylor Sheridan’s oil-industry drama trades in gender stereotypes, reactionary politics, and blatant product placement. Why, then, is it so damn satisfying?
item.media:keywords: Paramount, TV Shows, Series, Oil Companies
item.dc:creator: Kyle Chayka

item.title: Matthew Broderick Stars as the Titular Grifter in “Tartuffe”
item.description: It’s been the year of Molière, and therefore the year of the liar, the hypocrite, the poseur, the clown.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

item.title: The Best Performances of 2025
item.description: In a year when the entertainment industry embraced the artificial, extraordinary human acts—from Sarah Snook’s one-woman “Dorian Gray” to Michael B. Jordan’s twin turn in “Sinners”—made their mark.
item.media:keywords: Actors, Film, Theatre, Timothée Chalamet, Michael B. Jordan, Seth Rogen, Emma Stone, Bad Bunny (Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio)
item.dc:creator: Michael Schulman

item.title: Memory Speaks in “Marjorie Prime” and “Anna Christie”
item.description: Helen Shaw reviews “Marjorie Prime,” with June Squibb, Cynthia Nixon, and Danny Burstein,
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

item.title: The Best Theatre of 2025
item.description: It was a banner year for generation-defining performance, both up- and downtown.
item.media:keywords: Theatre, Plays, Musicals, Broadway, Off Broadway
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

item.title: The Organists Improvising Soundtracks to Silent Films
item.description: Early on, movies had no sound, but musicians provided live accompaniment. The tradition continues.
item.dc:creator: Alex Ross

item.title: A Year of Listening Beyond the Algorithm
item.description: A list of songs I loved in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Hanif Abdurraqib

item.title: Poetry as a Cistern for Love and Loss
item.description: The poet Gabrielle Calvocoressi talks with Kevin Young, The New Yorker’s poetry editor, about their newest collection, “The New Economy,” and poetry’s role in addressing grief.
item.category: Podcast / The New Yorker Radio Hour

item.title: Will Geese Redeem Noisy, Lawless Rock and Roll?
item.description: Critics love to make these kinds of breathless pronouncements. But with this band, currently on tour to promote its album “Getting Killed,” controlled hysteria is sort of the point.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Petrusich

item.title: “Helen Frankenthaler: A Grand Sweep,” Reviewed
item.description: In a small show at MOMA, Frankenthaler seems to make paint its own living force, untouched by an artist.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Fine

item.title: Lorenzo Mattotti’s “Goodbye to All That”
item.description: Onward and upward into 2026.
item.dc:creator: Françoise Mouly

item.title: The Top Twenty-five New Yorker Stories of 2025
item.description: Consider this your personal year-end reading list, one that we hope provides hours of pleasure.
item.dc:creator: Michael Luo

item.title: The Wild, Sad Life of John Cage’s First Lover
item.description: Whatever became of Don Sample?
item.category: Culture / Onward and Upward with the Arts
item.media:keywords: John Cage, Poets, Writers, Gay Men, Mattachine Society
item.dc:creator: Alex Ross

item.title: Ten of My Favorite Cookbooks of 2025
item.description: The year’s best culinary titles include a food history of the United States, a guide to being an excellent dinner-party guest, and a collection of recipes that people decided to take to their graves.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Goldfield

item.title: The Role of Doctors Is Changing Forever
item.description: Some patients don’t trust us. Others say they don’t need us. It’s time for us to think of ourselves not as the high priests of health care but as what we have always been: healers.
item.media:keywords: Health Care, Medicine, Doctors, Alternative Medicine, Health Insurance, Artificial Intelligence (A.I.), Social Media
item.dc:creator: Dhruv Khullar

item.title: Jim Jarmusch’s Ironically Optimistic Family Movie
item.description: Also: Graciela Iturbide’s tranquil photographs of Mexico, Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson in “Song Sung Blue,” the coke-rap of Clipse, and more.
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody, Brian Seibert, Sheldon Pearce, Zoë Hopkins, Helen Shaw, Rachel Syme

item.title: Rob Reiner Made a New Kind of Fairy Tale
item.description: The director’s great achievement was placing real people, with real senses of humor, into the fantasies of mass culture.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Schwartz

item.title: Is Cognitive Dissonance Actually a Thing?
item.description: A foundational 1956 study of the concept, focussed on a U.F.O. doomsday cult, has been all but debunked by new research.
item.dc:creator: Shayla Love

item.title: A Graphic Novel About Rage and Repression in Montreal
item.description: For the characters in Lee Lai’s “Cannon,” home is the place most resistant to real emotion.
item.media:keywords: Montreal, Graphic Novels, LGBTQ, Chinese, Asians, Diasporas
item.dc:creator: E. Tammy Kim
